member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.Attributes.Stats.MinPhysBaseDmgByRightWeapon
member.summary: Gets the minimum physical base DMG by right hand weapon attribute definition.
member.remarks: Used to isolate RH weapon min damage for double weapon wield logic. On a staff-sword (mixed) or double-staff wield (MG), the LH weapon alone dictates the "attack type": LH: staff; RH: sword/staff => LH physical damage and rise (ene-MG). LH: sword; RH: staff => LH physical damage (str-MG). Other than these, it's a "true" double wield (two one-handed physical weapons) and both weapons' damage attributes count. Summoner can also double weapon wield (stick and book), but books have no damage.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.ItemPowerUpFactory
member.summary: The implementation of the item power up factory.

member.name: M:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.ItemPowerUpFactory.#ctor(Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.ILogger{MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.ItemPowerUpFactory})
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.ItemPowerUpFactory.CreateExcellentAndAncientBasePowerUpWrappers(MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Entities.Item,MUnique.OpenMU.AttributeSystem.AttributeSystem)
member.summary: Creates power-up wrappers for excellent and ancient item bonuses. These bonuses are calculated dynamically based on item properties and drop levels.
member.param: The item to create power-ups for.
The attribute system to bind the power-ups to.
member.returns: Power-up wrappers for excellent and ancient bonuses.
member.remarks: Formula patterns: - Excellent Defense: (baseDefense * 12 / dropLevel) + (dropLevel / 5) + 4. - Ancient Defense: 2 + ((baseDefense + exBonus) * 3 / ancDropLevel) + (ancDropLevel / 30). - Excellent Physical Weapon: (minDmg * 25 / dropLevel) + 5. - Ancient Physical Weapon: 5 + (ancDropLevel / 40). - Excellent Wizardry: ((staffRise * 2 * 25 / dropLevel) + 5) / 2. - Ancient Wizardry: (2 + (ancDropLevel / 60)) / 2.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.ItemPriceCalculator
member.summary: This calculator calculates the item prices.
member.remarks: At the moment it looks all pretty hard coded (like at the original server), so maybe in a future version we could write a more generic calculator, which can be influenced by configuration instead of hard-coded item ids. A nice approach would be to have a "rule" for each item definition, about how to calculate the price.

member.name: M:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.ItemPriceCalculator.CalculateSellingPrice(MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Entities.Item)
member.summary: Calculates the selling price of the item for its maximum durability.
member.returns: The selling price.

member.name: M:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.ItemPriceCalculator.CalculateSellingPrice(MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Entities.Item,System.Byte)
member.summary: Calculates the selling price of the item, which the player gets if he is selling an item to a merchant. It's usually a third of the buying price, minus a durability factor.
member.returns: The selling price.

member.name: M:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.ItemPriceCalculator.CalculateRepairPrice(MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Entities.Item,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Calculates the repair price of the item, which the player has to pay if he wants to repair the item.
member.param: If set to true, the item is repaired through an NPC which gives a discount.
member.returns: The repair price.

member.name: M:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.ItemPriceCalculator.CalculateFinalBuyingPrice(MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Entities.Item)
member.summary: Calculates the final buying price of the item, which the player has to pay if he wants to buy the item from a merchant.
member.returns: The buying price.

member.name: M:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.ItemPriceCalculator.CalculateFinalOldBuyingPrice(MUnique.OpenMU.DataModel.Entities.Item)
member.summary: Calculates the final "old" buying price of the item. Supposedly in earlier versions jewel reference prices were different, and those were used since for Chaos Weapon and First Wings craftings rate calculations.
member.returns: The "old" buying price.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.MiniGames.BloodCastleContext
member.summary: The context of a blood castle game.
member.remarks:
A blood castle event works like that: First, a player or his party (and probably another party), maximum 10 players, enter the blood castle. The game has several states: * After the event starts, first a certain amount of monsters have to be killed, so that a bridge appears on the way to the castle gate. * The castle gate has to be destroyed * Some stronger monsters wait after the castle gate. A certain amount of "Spirit Sorcerer" have to be killed. * The statue appears, which needs to be killed. * The statue drops an archangel weapon as quest item. This item has to be brought back to the archangel NPC. The game has a time limit of usually 15 or 20 minutes. After the time is up, or the quest item has been brought back, the players get some rewards:
Experience: 1. For each remaining second, a bonus experience is given as experience. 2. The player or party which destroyed the gate, gets extra experience. Dead party members get the half of the exp as bonus. 3. For killing the statue, the player/party gets a bonus experience. 4. For finishing the quest, the player/party gets a bonus experience. 5. To all previous exp rewards, bonuses from seals, maps etc. are applied. Money: According to the reward table - fixed values per blood castle level, depending if the player was in the winning party, or not. The winner/winners party get roughly the double money value. Score: a) If the event was won by any participant, depending on the individual success state of a player, it will get a different score rewarded. A player is categorized into these 5 states: - unfinished event - died during event - winner - member of winners party - member of winners party, but died during event. b) If the event wasn't won by any participant, players are getting a score penalty of 300.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.MiniGames.ChaosCastleContext
member.summary: The context of a chaos castle game.
member.remarks:
A chaos castle event works like that: First, one to 70 players enter the chaos castle. The map starts as a safezone. Then the event starts: * The map terrain is redefined of not being a safezone anymore. * The map is filled up to 100 objects with NPCs Then, these objects fight each other. If the player dies, the event is over for that player. If a npc dies, it doesn't re-spawn. There is a 50% chance, that a died monster explodes and moves players nearby (range 3) by , depending on the distance to the killed monster. During the game, the map is getting smaller (so-called "Trap Status") after a certain amount of objects died at the following number of remaining objects: * less than 40 * less than 30 * less than 20 A player has won, if: 1) It's the last remaining object on the map 2) The time is up and it has the highest kill count Rewards: A jewel and/or an ancient item.
Different to the original chaos castle, we don't apply additional damage when players get moved.

member.summary: An intelligence for guard NPCs.
member.remarks: This behavior could be refined in the following way: - When a player with active self defense against a PK talks to him, it could set a follow mode on this player and remembers the PK as target. - When the player walks back to the PK and the guard comes into range, the guard stops following and starts attacking the PK. - Follow mode is disabled after a timeout and the guard walks or teleports back.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerActions.ItemConsumeActions.ApplyMagicEffectConsumeHandlerPlugIn
member.summary: for s which have a defined .

Consumes the item at the specified slot with the specified effect and reduces its durability by one. If the durability has reached 0, the item is getting destroyed. If a target slot is specified, the consumption targets the item on this slot (e.g. upgrade of an item by a jewel).
member.param: The item which is the target of the consumption (e.g. upgrade target of a jewel).
In case the item is a fruit, this parameter defines how the fruit should be used.
member.returns: The success of the consumption.

member.name: T:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerState
member.summary: The states of a player, used by the .

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerState.Finished
member.summary: Gets the finished state. When this state is active, the player session was saved and the player object can be safely removed from the game.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerState.Disconnected
member.summary: Gets the disconnected state. When this state is active, the player disconnected from the game, but his session is not saved yet.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerState.EnteredWorld
member.summary: Gets the entered world state. When this state is active, the player entered the world with one of his characters.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerState.Dead
member.summary: Gets the dead state. When this state is active, the player has been killed with one of his characters.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerState.CharacterSelection
member.summary: Gets the character selection state. When this state is active, the character selection screen is shown.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerState.Authenticated
member.summary: Gets the authenticated state. When this state is active, the player has been successfully authenticated.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerState.LoginScreen
member.summary: Gets the login screen state. When this state is active, the login screen is shown to the player.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerState.Initial
member.summary: Gets the initial state.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerState.ChangingMap
member.summary: Gets the changing map state.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerState.TradeRequested
member.summary: Gets the trade requested state. When this state is active, a player got requested by another player to open a trade.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerState.TradeOpened
member.summary: Gets the trade opened state. When this state is active, the player has a trade going on.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerState.TradeButtonPressed
member.summary: Gets the trade button pressed state. When this state is active, the player pressed its trade button to close his trade.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerState.NpcDialogOpened
member.summary: Gets the Monster dialog opened state. When this state is active, the player has opened a Monster dialog.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerState.PartyRequest
member.summary: Gets the party request state. When this state is active, the player has requested for party.

member.name: P:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.PlayerState.GuildRequest
member.summary: Gets the guild request state. When this state is active, the player has requested for guild. Note: This state is currently unused. Guild requests are tracked via the property instead.

member.name: M:MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.Views.ViewExtensions.GetId(MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.IIdentifiable,MUnique.OpenMU.GameLogic.Player)
member.summary: Gets the of the if it's not the same object instance as ; Otherwise, the is returned.
member.returns: The of the if it's not the same object instance as ; Otherwise, the is returned.
member.remarks: This allows us to give players a dynamic , depending on the current game map. And the dynamic id allows us to add players of different game server instances to the same map instance without forcing the player client connect to another server. Examples for such shared maps are loren valley, crywolf, land of trials, loren market etc.

member.summary: Gets the object with the specified id which is on the same map as the specified player.
member.returns: The object with the specified id which is on the same map as the specified player.
